mcqs.question: According to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) guidelines, which criterion defines severe obesity in adolescents aged 10-19 years?

options.B: BMI ≥120% of the 95th percentile for age and sex or BMI ≥35 kg/m²

mcqs.explanation: Severe obesity in adolescents is defined as a BMI at or above 120% of the 95th percentile for age and sex or a BMI of 35 kg/m² or higher, based on AAP recommendations.

mcqs.question: When is bariatric surgery considered for adolescents with severe obesity?

options.A: As first-line treatment for all cases
options.D: For adolescents under 16 years regardless of comorbidities

mcqs.explanation: Bariatric surgery is an evidence-based treatment option for carefully selected adolescents who have failed comprehensive lifestyle modification and have significant comorbidities.

mcqs.question: What percentage of adolescent bariatric surgery patients are female according to Teen-LABS data?
mcqs.explanation: Females represent approximately 70% of adolescent bariatric surgery patients according to Teen-LABS data.

mcqs.question: What is the mean age at surgery for adolescents undergoing bariatric procedures?
mcqs.explanation: The mean age at surgery for adolescents is 16-17 years.

mcqs.question: Which cutaneous finding is commonly associated with severe obesity in adolescents and indicates insulin resistance?
mcqs.explanation: Acanthosis nigricans is a hyperpigmented, velvety skin lesion often seen in severe obesity, serving as a marker for insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.

mcqs.question: Which syndrome is associated with severe obesity in adolescents?
mcqs.explanation: Associated anomalies include Prader-Willi syndrome, Bardet-Biedl syndrome, Alström syndrome, and leptin receptor deficiency.

mcqs.question: Which condition is part of the differential diagnosis for severe obesity?
mcqs.explanation: Differential diagnosis includes endocrine disorders like Cushing syndrome, hypothyroidism, medication-induced weight gain, genetic obesity syndromes, and hypothalamic obesity.

mcqs.question: What is the first-line treatment for severe obesity in adolescents?
mcqs.explanation: Comprehensive lifestyle intervention, involving structured diet, physical activity, and behavioral therapy, is the initial treatment for severe obesity in adolescents.

mcqs.question: What percentage of adolescent bariatric surgery cases are sleeve gastrectomy?
mcqs.explanation: Sleeve gastrectomy accounts for 85-90% of adolescent bariatric surgery cases.

mcqs.question: What is the goal for daily protein intake after bariatric surgery?
mcqs.explanation: The goal for protein intake after surgery is 60-80 g/day.

mcqs.question: How often is laboratory monitoring typically performed in the first year after surgery?
mcqs.explanation: Follow-up protocols include laboratory monitoring at 3, 6, 12 months, then annually.

mcqs.question: What is the mean BMI reduction at 3 years post-surgery?
mcqs.explanation: The mean BMI reduction at 3 years is 30-35%.

mcqs.question: Which complication is higher after sleeve gastrectomy compared to other procedures?
mcqs.explanation: GERD occurs in 5-15% of cases and is higher after sleeve gastrectomy.

mcqs.question: What percentage of surgical candidates have vitamin D deficiency?
mcqs.explanation: Vitamin D deficiency is present in 40-60% of surgical candidates.
